topic.title: Extending Qodana
topic.p: Although %product% provides various profiles for inspecting your code, it may be useful to analyze your codebase using third-party inspections that are not covered by standard %product% profiles. This can done in several ways, such as:

chapter.title: Plugins from JetBrains Marketplace
chapter.p: JetBrains Marketplace provides plugins for inspecting code in the IDE. These plugins can be used to extend %product% inspection functionality.
To extend %product% with a third-party plugin, you need to accomplish these steps:

list.li: Install the plugin to your IDE and enable the required inspections
Create the XML-formatted profile file containing the enabled inspections
Mount the plugin file to the %product% linter image
Specify the profile file in qodana.yaml.

chapter.p: This section explains how to inspect your PHP code using the linter and extended with the plugin inspections. All actions taken in the IDE are explained for PhpStorm. You can reproduce all these steps for practically any plugin you would like to extend %product% with.

procedure.step: To install and enable the plugin in your IDE, follow instructions from the Php Inspections (EA Extended) page on the PhpStorm documentation portal. This step is required for creating the profile file in the IDE. You can also reuse the plugin file for running %product% with it. Alternatively, you can download the plugin package from the JetBrains Marketplace and save it to the directory that can be accessible to %product%.
Save the updated profile file containing the enabled plugin inspections in your IDE as described in the section. This file will become available depending on the profile type:

Optionally, you may need additional plugin configuration options that are usually configured in the Settings window of your IDE. Such file is available in the options subdirectory of the configuration directory of your IDE. In case of the plugin, this step may be required for specifying Yoda style rules.
In the project root directory, create the qodana.yaml file and specify the profile location.

chapter.title: Structural search
chapter.p: Structural search lets you inspect your code based on a particular code pattern or grammatical construct in your code.
For demonstration purposes, this section uses the $Instance$.$MethodCall$($Parameter$) search template using these filters:

tr.td: Any text enclosed in the pair of quote (") characters.

chapter.p: This template lets you search for the System.out.println() Java statement with hardcoded text like System.out.println("Hardcoded text!").
